Frequently Asked Questions

Is the Tree Trout real?

It’s a playful conservation myth with roots in forest folklore—and a lens for learning about canopy ecology.

Why is it endangered?

Habitat fragmentation, reduced fog drip, and loss of epiphytic moss pools threaten the conditions that make Tree Trout possible.

Where can I see one?

High-elevation spruce/fir stands during foggy mornings. Watch for ripples in canopy pools and subtle branch jostling.

Does it leave the trees?

Seasonally—descents coincide with nutrient redistribution and understory foraging.

How is this different from other sites?

We focus on canopy hydrology, citizen science, and joyful curiosity over strict taxonomy.

How can I help?

Support stewardship groups, report sightings, and avoid disturbing epiphytic mats.

What about evolution?

Models suggest divergence from stream trout during pluvial periods, with selection for vertical niches.

Related creatures?

Canopy salamanders, gliding squirrels, and various moths share microhabitats and occasionally interact.

Is this just copying another site?

We honor satirical conservation roots but emphasize forest science, hydrology, and community action unique to the Rockies.
